intro: Limodorum occidentale, commonly known as the western lily of the valley, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant produces a fragrant, tubular flower that attracts pollinators such as bees and moths. Its leaves are broad, lance-shaped, and arranged in a rosette at the base of the plant. Limodorum occidentale thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories.
